questions.question: Are the windows aligned vertically in the same columns across all floors?
questions.explanation: In Image B, the windows appear to be symmetrically aligned in a typical building layout where each vertical column of windows is directly above the corresponding windows on the floors above and below. This alignment is common in multi-story residential buildings to maintain architectural symmetry and structural integrity.

questions.question: Is there a red door located on the left side of the ground floor?
questions.explanation: In Image B, there is a distinct red door visible on the left side of the ground floor. This is identifiable by its unique color, which contrasts with the surrounding brick façade, and its position at the entrance level of the building.

questions.question: Is there a dark-colored door located on the right side of the ground floor?
questions.explanation: In Image B, a dark-colored door is present on the right side of the ground floor. This is noticeable through its darker hue compared to the red door and its positioning on the ground level entrance of the building.

questions.question: Does the climbing plant cover the central vertical strip of the building, spanning from near the ground floor up to the third floor?
questions.explanation: In Image B, a climbing plant is visually covering the central vertical strip of the building. It extends from near the ground floor, climbing upwards and seemingly reaching up to the third floor, creating a green vertical line across the building façade.

questions.question: Is there a red rectangular outline enclosing a section of the building that includes three stacked windows and a balcony?
questions.explanation: In Image B, there is no red rectangular outline visible enclosing any section of the building. The clean layout of the image indicates pure architectural elements without additional framing or outlining.

questions.question: Are the balconies located directly outside specific windows on the second, third, and fourth floors?
questions.explanation: In Image B, balconies are perfectly aligned outside specific windows on each of the mentioned floors. The regular placement follows a typical architectural style where balconies serve as extensions and are directly accessible from the adjacent room or space.
